summary: trophoblasts produce numerous immunomodulators that play a role in placental development and pregnancy maintenance. we hypothesize that FIV infection may cause dysregulation of trophoblast immunomodulator expression, and aberrant expression of these molecules may potentiate inflammation. trophoblasts express anti-inflammatory immunomodulators whose expression increases from early to late pregnancy in normal tissues. non-viable pregnancies were associated with decreased expression of immunomodulators which regulate trophoblast invasion in other species. the detection of FIV RNA in trophoblasts was rare. trophoblastic cells were efficiently infected with cell associated virus [13], but not cell free virus [14] due to differences in entry pathways into the cell. in the latter case, virus production was marginally increased by treatment with TNF- and IL-1. 10 cats were inoculated intravenously with 1 ml of a feline plasma pool containing approximately 1.3 104 copies/ml of FIV-B-2542. infection was confirmed within 6 weeks p.i. by detection of FIV provirus by PCR and for seroconversion using the petChek® FIV Antibody Test Kit. [17,27] Placenta FIV Status/Ct value 2779 Placenta B Early - Viable NT - 2779 Placenta E Early - Non-viable; resorption NT - 0326 Placenta A Early + Viable + + - 8035 Placenta B Early + Non-viable; arrested + - 8035 Placenta C Early + Non-viable; arrested + + - NT = not tested Immuno trophoblasts were microdissected using the veritasTM microdissection instrument. similar fields of 2.00 mm2 were collected onto CapSure Macro LCM Caps. RNA purification and quantification from microdissected tissues RNA was extracted from microdissected trophoblasts of FIV-B-2542-infected and uninfected queens. each reverse transcription reaction was performed in a final reaction volume of 20 l containing 2 l of the 10X RT buffer, 2 l RT random primers, 0.8 l of 25X dNTP, 1 l of Multiscribe Reverse Transcriptase, 1 l of RNase-free water, and 10 l of 30-800 pg RNA template. all cDNA was stored at -20°C until used. simplex reactions on separate plates for each gene. trophoblasts were labeled using antibody to cytokeratin. cytokeratin labeling was specific for trophoblasts. expression of FIV gag in trophoblasts was detected in only a single, late-term. trophoblasts Messenger RNA for IL-4, IL-5, IL-6, IL-1, IL-12p35, IL-12p40, and CXCR4 was expressed in all early- and late-term all immunomodulators were amplified from RNA extracted from whole placental tissues used for generating standard curves. failure to detect some of them in trophoblasts was not a result of inadequate qPCR conditions. only IL-5 did not differ between the two stages of pregnancy (p = 0.135) trophoblasts from non-viable pregnancies expressed significantly less IL-4 (p = 0.032), IL-6 (p = 0.048), IL-12p35 (p = 0.001), and CXCR4 (p = 0.004) mRNA than those of viable pregnancies. trophoblasts from non-viable pregnancies expressed significantly less IL-4 (p = 0.032), IL-6 (p = 0.048), IL-12 trophoblasts from non-viable pregnancies expressed significantly less IL-4 (p = 0.021), IL-12p35 (p = 0.021), and IL-12p40 (p = 0.038) than trophoblasts from viable pregnancies. real-time RT-PCR analysis of trophoblast expression of the pro-inflammatory cytokines (IL-6, IL-1, IL-12p35, and IL-12p40) expression of FIV gag in trophoblasts was detected in only a single, late-term trophoblast specimen, collected from a placenta trophoblasts. IL-12p40, and CXCR4 mRNA than trophoblasts from control cats at early gestation. only IL-5 did not differ between the two stages of pregnancy. expression of the anti-inflammatory cytokines was decreased to a significant level. at late gestation, trophoblasts from non-viable pregnancies expressed significantly less IL-4 (p = 0.021), IL-12p35 (p = 0.021), and IL-12p40 (p = 0.038) at late gestation, trophoblasts from non-viable pregnancies expressed significantly less IL-4 (p = 0.032), IL-6 (p = 0.048), IL-12p35 (p = 0.001), and C the anti-inflammatory cytokines (IL-4 and IL-5) and the chemokine receptor (CXCR4) in early-(A) and late-term placesntas versus all non-viable (n = 4 each for early and late tissues) pregnancies. bars represent mean Ct values substracted from a negative endpoint (60-mean Ct), bracketed by standard errors. expression of IL-4, IL-5, IL-6, IL-1, IL-12p35, IL-12p40, and CXCR4 in feline placental trophoblasts at both time points during feline gestation. at early gestation, FIV infection was associated with slightly decreased expression of all cytokines, although only the expression of IL-5 decreased to significant levels. IL-4 mediates the process of trophoblast invasion during human placentation. IL-4 activates matrix metalloprotease 3 (MMP-3), a protease that digests extracellular matrix proteins. this interaction protects trophoblasts from apoptosis via stimulation of anti-apoptotic pathways. cultured placental trophoblasts from HIV-infected women expressed significantly higher amounts of IL-1, IL-6, and TNF- than placentas from uninfected women. this indicates that HIV-infection during pregnancy results in increased cytokine expression and that a pro-inflammatory microenvironment exists in HIV-infected placentas. our laboratory is investigating feline Tregs and Th17 cells in lentivirus-induced placental immunopathology and pregnancy failure. a limitation of this study was the small number of tissues evaluated by LCM, particularly in terms of separating viable versus non-viable tissues. the inclusion of additional placental specimens may have strengthened the statistical power. trophoblasts expressed anti-inflammatory immunomodulators whose expression increased from early to late pregnancy in normal tissues. non-viable pregnancies were associated with decreased expression of immunomodulators which regulate trophoblast invasion in other species. project was supported by the national institutes of health (2R15AI048419-02A1) and (3R15AI048419-02A1S1).
